commit_list.message: Update readme file names to match "-2" Heroku rev

Use PHP built with --enable-sockets

Again, this flag was not seen in old versions, so it's unclear how
this functionality, per secondary report, was regressed.

Build instructions updated accordingly.

Update binary vendoring steps in README

For Apache 2.2.25 and PHP 5.3.27.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

* Silence GNU Make steps via '-s' to quiet down builds (warnings are
  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default
  paths and can't be done in-dyno.  This makes the steps for dealing
  with 'APC' much simpler.

* Use default responses for prompts when building APC rather than
  prompting the builder.

* Sanitize cgi-bin of default Apache programs.

* Create binary-vendoring tarballs with the same name that they are
  intended to be uploaded as.

  Notably, name of the tarball and the directory contained within that
  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.
Use new Apache and PHP binaries

Remove unnecessary 'use' forms

Fix a laundry list of warnings involving unused imports that glutted
up compilation output.  There are more, but there seems to be some
false positives (where 'remedy' appears to break the build), but this
particular set of fixes seems safe.
Increment copyright year of time.rs

Use passing by-value in gmtime, mktime

Per the recommendation of the now-removed FIXME.
Pick up PHP with --enable-sockets after v10 of the build pack

commit_list.message:
Un-break el-get when installing rust-mode

rust-mode no longer requires cm-mode, and furthermore, cm-mode has
been removed from the Rust repository.  That means that without this
patch updating one's rust-mode will break one's .emacs initialization.

Fix this by simply removing the dependency metadata.

Fix nullity of `body` in tests

After re-running the migrations in the last commit, `bundle exec
rspec` will fail because the test attempts to create a Todo record
with a null `body`.

So, give it some text to satisfy the non-null constraint.

At this point, we can try issuing some requests against a live server:

Start the server. Here the server's output is shown interleaved with
some shell activity to create and list todo items:

```
[fdr@perseverance todo-app]$ foreman start &
[1] 15281
00:12:04 web.1  | started with pid 15311
00:12:04 web.1  | [15311] Puma starting in cluster mode...
00:12:04 web.1  | [15311] * Version 2.16.0 (ruby 2.3.1-p112), codename: Midwinter Nights Trance
00:12:04 web.1  | [15311] * Min threads: 1, max threads: 16
00:12:04 web.1  | [15311] * Environment: development
00:12:04 web.1  | [15311] * Process workers: 3
00:12:04 web.1  | [15311] * Preloading application
00:12:05 web.1  | [15311] * Listening on tcp://0.0.0.0:5000
00:12:05 web.1  | [15311] Use Ctrl-C to stop
00:12:05 web.1  | [15311] - Worker 0 (pid: 15315) booted, phase: 0
00:12:05 web.1  | [15311] - Worker 1 (pid: 15322) booted, phase: 0
00:12:05 web.1  | [15311] - Worker 2 (pid: 15329) booted, phase: 0
```

Print the list of todos:

```
[fdr@perseverance todo-app]$ curl http://localhost:5000/todos

00:12:37 web.1  | app=todo-app deployment=development request_id=c681680c-b9ee-412d-9520-ee0f2344d872 instrumentation method=GET path=/todos at=start
[]    # This is the output: an empty list.
00:12:37 web.1  | app=todo-app deployment=development request_id=c681680c-b9ee-412d-9520-ee0f2344d872 instrumentation method=GET path=/todos route_signature=/todos at=finish status=200 length=3 elapsed=0.023
```

Store a new todo item:

```
[fdr@perseverance todo-app]$ echo '{"body": "buy eggs"}' | curl -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X POST -d '@-' http://localhost:5000/todos
00:20:29 web.1  | app=todo-app deployment=development request_id=32c421a6-e50b-488d-aab2-7e98bfd19987 instrumentation method=POST path=/todos at=start
00:20:29 web.1  | {"body"=>"buy eggs"}
00:20:29 web.1  | app=todo-app deployment=development request_id=32c421a6-e50b-488d-aab2-7e98bfd19987 instrumentation method=POST path=/todos route_signature=/todos at=finish status=201 length=138 elapsed=0.029
{
  "created_at":"2016-11-08T08:20:29+00:00",
  "id":"d11afd17-dbb2-4a70-bc61-823baffd49ca",
  "updated_at":"2016-11-08T08:20:29+00:00"
}
```

Read out the list again, noticing there is a non-empty list returned:

```
[fdr@perseverance todo-app]$ curl http://localhost:5000/todos
00:21:04 web.1  | app=todo-app deployment=development request_id=72a038f2-e097-4b5f-93d8-97f38c6ea211 instrumentation method=GET path=/todos at=start
[
  {
    "created_at":"2016-11-08T08:20:29+00:00",
    "id":"d11afd17-dbb2-4a70-bc61-823baffd49ca",
    "updated_at":"2016-11-08T08:20:29+00:00"

  }
]
00:21:04 web.1  | app=todo-app deployment=development request_id=72a038f2-e097-4b5f-93d8-97f38c6ea211 instrumentation method=GET path=/todos route_signature=/todos at=finish status=200 length=152 elapsed=0.001
```

Add "body" field

This will hold the text of a todo item.

Because we modified a migration in-place, which is an expedient, it's
necessary to re-migrate the database from scratch, by running `bundle
exec rake db:setup` again.

Remove response schema checking: out of scope

`bundle exec rspec` should pass now.

Schemas might be useful for avoiding regressions in output format in
more complex programs, but for now they are a distraction.

Add scaffold to routes.rb

This is per the instruction in the output of `pliny-generate`,
repeated here:

```
[fdr@perseverance todo-app]$ pliny-generate scaffold todo
created endpoint file ./lib/endpoints/todos.rb
add the following to lib/routes.rb:
  mount Endpoints::Todos
created test ./spec/endpoints/todos_spec.rb
created test ./spec/acceptance/todos_spec.rb
created model file ./lib/models/todo.rb
created migration ./db/migrate/1478587789_create_todos.rb
created test ./spec/models/todo_spec.rb
created schema file ./schema/schemata/todo.yaml
rebuilt ./schema/schema.json
created serializer file ./lib/serializers/todo.rb
created test ./spec/serializers/todo_spec.rb
```

Without this, the new endpoints won't be added to the web server and
everything will return "404 not found".

Add fresh scaffolds

This is the result of `pliny-generate scaffold todo`.

commit_list.message:
Update binary vendoring steps in README

For Apache 2.2.25 and PHP 5.3.27.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

* Silence GNU Make steps via '-s' to quiet down builds (warnings are
  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default
  paths and can't be done in-dyno.  This makes the steps for dealing
  with 'APC' much simpler.

* Use default responses for prompts when building APC rather than
  prompting the builder.

* Sanitize cgi-bin of default Apache programs.

* Create binary-vendoring tarballs with the same name that they are
  intended to be uploaded as.

  Notably, name of the tarball and the directory contained within that
  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.

commit_list.message:
Use America/Los_Angeles timezone for queries

Right now, the 'current' day rolls over when UTC-time passes into the
next calendar day.  Given the maximum offset from UTC in
America/Los_Angeles is eight hours, the current day is hidden pretty
early (4 or 5 PM, depending on PST/PDT switch), which can get in the
way of checking in guests for evening activities.

So, use the 'America/Los_Angeles' time zone, which will automatically
adjust given the time of year to apply the right offsets when
truncating to the "date" type.  Rollovers will happen at midnight,
relative to Heroku HQ.
Update dependencies

Mute all the colors a bit

Whites, blacks, greens, and reds have all been softened significantly.
Remove spurious newlines

Print "nobody" for days with no visitors

This makes them stand out a bit more.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

* Silence GNU Make steps via '-s' to quiet down builds (warnings are
  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default
  paths and can't be done in-dyno.  This makes the steps for dealing
  with 'APC' much simpler.

* Use default responses for prompts when building APC rather than
  prompting the builder.

* Sanitize cgi-bin of default Apache programs.

* Create binary-vendoring tarballs with the same name that they are
  intended to be uploaded as.

  Notably, name of the tarball and the directory contained within that
  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.

Notably, it appears to parse URLs differently, and that is enough to

simplify automatic binary release with Travis, make the default build
target both run the tests and compile the main-package binary for

Per https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/deployment/releases/
Compress and preserve executable bits
Rename katie31 to wal-g org
Remove self-duplicative vendor
Add Patrick Figel as a contributor
Add Will Glynn to CONTRIBUTORS

Add OS, arch information to release tarball name

This naming convention was copied from https://golang.org/dl/ and
gives us some wiggle room if we go on to have releases on multiple
platforms.

Remove unnecessary 'use' forms

Fix a laundry list of warnings involving unused imports that glutted
up compilation output.  There are more, but there seems to be some
false positives (where 'remedy' appears to break the build), but this
particular set of fixes seems safe.

commit_list.message:
Exempt more processes from throttling to prevent priority inversions

In particular, the goal is to enable checkpoints to continue
un-impeded so that trimming of the WAL on-disk can take place in a
more regular manner, reducing disk usage faster.
commit_list.repo_description: Slowing things down via SIGSTOP/SIGCONT on Linux

commit_list.message:
Fix ratchet waking up processes

Wups.

Notably this doesn't show up in the self-test because the tests do not
go to the trouble of modeling a supervisor process with forked child
processes.
commit_list.repo_description: Slowing things down via SIGSTOP/SIGCONT on Linux

commit_list.message:
Deprecate busted functionality, fix priority inversion

Attempt to skip the postmaster and the logger in addition to the
archiver when sleeping.

Deprecate the renicing targets, because it wasn't being used and would
require refactoring to support the new definition of processes exempt
from throttling.

Remove test output summary, because it was always broken, but it
doesn't seem important right now to fix it.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>
commit_list.repo_description: Slowing things down via SIGSTOP/SIGCONT on Linux

commit_list.message:
Avoid crashing in event of a slept-process exiting

The loop as previously seen could crash when a process exits normally
or otherwise while SIGCONTs are being sent.  Just use some of the
machinery from the 'wake' command which takes care of this better.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>
commit_list.repo_description: Slowing things down via SIGSTOP/SIGCONT on Linux

commit_list.message:
Make default nap much more aggressive

The old nap is known to not give a busy server much breathing space to
archive faster than it writes, but *this* default definitely does.

commit_list.message:
Backpatch net/http: avoid a bunch of unnecessary CanonicalHeaderKey calls

changeset:   13637:3ad9da69a1a7
parent:      13635:40dc2beda77f
user:        Brad Fitzpatrick <bradfitz@golang.org>
date:        Mon May 28 11:07:24 2012 -0700
summary:     net/http: avoid a bunch of unnecessary CanonicalHeaderKey calls

To my naive eyes, it seems like this refactoring missed completion (it
seems like .get is a fast path for all literally-provided header
names), but nevertheless faithfully complete what the patch does, no
more, and no less.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

in their respective files, and also attempted to retain the same file
names for tracking where the definitions have come from in the source
implementation.

commit_list.message:
Support timestamp without tz, redux

This time, some more effort has been paid to testing on an older Go
version, 1.0.2, and carefully preserving the old hacks to make time
parsing work with those older versions with a less useful time.Parse.
It has also been tested on Go 1.0.3.

This just lets the Go time package use its default behavior when one
is left without time offset information.  Hope it is a behavior people
want.

The main change here is pushing down the column type into the parsing
function, as Go's time parsing can't deal with data that only has the
fractional-hour timezone offset when such a fraction exists
(e.g. "-07" for "-07:00", but "-7:30" necessarily retaining its
precision).  This old hack could not be applied unconditionally (it is
wrong when the timestamp has no time zone offset suffix), so this
information lets a correct decision be made.

Clearly, this approach also can't handle the Postgres datestyle
parameter, but that's a fight to pick some other time.

As a target of opportunity, move the 'oid' type to 'types.go', since
for now all oids I know of handled by the program are type oids.  This
causes 'go fmt' to go a little nuts and rewrite the long but boring
file.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Readme fixups

Track the new changes to BufferMessage and stop using a busted example
(a procid with spaces).

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Add missing structured-data header to Syslog formatting

As-is the first space-delimited word of log output would get eaten as
the message id.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Fix Bundle swapout

Busted because I forgot that it's a by-pointer field MiniStats.  A
demonstration in a way which := with type inference can be somewhat
deceptive in some scenarios.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Add explicit runtime.Gosched to prevent starvation

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Remove superfluous blank-bindings

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Add missing error propagation

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Add host argument to BufferMessage

This is a prescribed-useful degree of freedom in the logplex docs.
Will break dependents noisily.  The next time this needs to be done,
switch to a struct so new fields can be accrued without breaking
dependents.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Fix resource leak; optimize

A bogus stat lock was causing goroutines to not exit in a timely
manner.  It's not entirely clear why things worked even semi-well
before.  This was exposed by moving the token-bucket grabbing from a
concurrent goroutine into the caller of BufferMessage, which can
prevent many short-lived goroutines that must be scheduled from ever
being born.

It seems like with this change that resident memory is stable.

Performance is about 10-20% slower in the synthetic benchmarks when
GOMAXPROCS=1 (no SMP parallelism or the interlocking that requires),
but is considerably faster in situations where channels require
interlock (GOMAXPROCS > 1), where the approach of eliminating channel
interactions at the cost of slowing down the synchronous part of
BufferMessages a little is more worthwhile.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Remove pointless blank-bindings

Channels don't need to use any bindings unblock when the other side is
closed.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Switch to empty structs for some signaling channels

This signals the semantic meaning of the payload of these channels
that only exist to synchronize rather than transmit data a little bit
better: wheres before there were two legitimate values (for Boolean
channels), there is now only one: the empty struct.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Update README.md

Track a change in the API.

Add micro-benchmarks

In addition to monitoring performance, these also provide some minimal
amount of smoke testing to see if things are halfway sane when dealing
with lots of log throughput and goroutines, as well as giving one a
sense of the logplexc-mostly overhead for processing a reasonably long
log message.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Exit on error rather than continuing

Otherwise a panic will occur from lobbing around nil values.  Mea
culpa.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Move empty-request-prevention guard

Previously, in some situations it was possible to sample statistics
and then try to send an empty request.  Instead, just swap Bundles
blindly (without checking statistics first) and do nothing with said
Bundle should it be empty.  Since Bundles are nominally immutable
after being produced by SwapBundle, it should become impossible to
send a Bundle that is empty.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Add special case for TargetLogLatency == 0

A bit of a rough hack, but if such a latency is passed, bypass the
ticker goroutine altogether.

An alternative would be to tune the RequestSizeTrigger to zero, but
this is an exposed field, and modifying its value to not be that which
the caller has passed in the configuration seems to violate the
principle of least astonishment.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Amend README to take into account removed Transport field

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Rely on return value rather than side effect of closure execution

Less action at a distance this way, and not any longer.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Give up on by-value semantics for the Transport

As it is now an interface, it is now passed by reference anyway, so
just give up on trying to attain safety by copying http.Transport.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Demand a RoundTripper, not a http.Transport

As it turns out, http.Transport is an implementation of only one such
transport, a sort of okay one intended to be used for network traffic
(too bad it doesn't have an obvious place where one can introduce
timeouts).

One might expect that http.Transport should be the interface type, and
what it currently is should be named something else, but for whatever
reason things are not this way.

Discovered when trying to figure out how to implement client timeouts
implemented via connection SetDeadline, and realizing it seems as
though one will have to write an entire RoundTripper to do so cleanly.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>
Initial commit
Pick up PHP with --enable-sockets after v10 of the build pack

Use the user name "dyno" in the Docker driver

Heroku defines the dyno user's human readable name to be "dyno".  Adapt
to match in this respect.

commit_list.message:
Add and use gob poller for self-invocations

This piggybacks on the CONTROL_DIR json-demarshalling structures to
serialize a gob passed by environment, allowing hsup to invoke itself
inside containers in both build and execution phases with rich
information and through a single mechanism, cleaning up all the
inspection of how hsup was configured when pushing data into the
sub-invocation.

Unlike the other pollers, the gob poller will only ever send exactly one
"Processes" value.

Detailed design information follows:

While this patch solves more problems than it creates, it exposes and
exacerbates some cracks in the software engineering:

Firstly, the guts of one poller (the "ControlDir") is shared between two
pollers, one of which has nothing to do with a directories.  To make
matters worse, its serialization/deserialization is in the guts of a
DynoDriver.

Superficially, this is an alarming destruction of abstraction barriers,
but not so much in light of what a "ControlDir" is at a detailed level:
to be a compact, no-frills, serializable data structure describing all
the same data any poller needs to respond.  It is the concrete variant
of the interface-driven approach used to return data from pollers
thusfar (e.g. the "Formation" interface).

In light of how useful serializing rich values to instruct descended
hsup processes is, perhaps all pollers ought to be adjusted to yield a
single, concrete implementation (that would be exactly like
"ControlDir") rather than support any kind of polymorphism via
interfaces as is currently the case.

This organizational and naming snarl is worthwhile removing if this
patch survives service to a larger goal: making the CONTROL_DIR
functionality work, and in particular supporting both http and
file-driven image building.  Before, this was busted and it appeared it
some futzing around with volumes and binds to fix it, but I found this
harder than anticipated when trying to achieve it.

On this unexpected difficulty: I chose this design after experimenting
with another.  That approach was using the CONTROL_DIR format to teach
the hsup self-invocation what to do.  Implied in this is file
generation, manipulation, and particularly sharing, and in this are the
seeds of that approach's undoing:

* There a lot more that can go wrong that requires error handling in
  code paths where one can do without such failure modes.

* Dockerfiles don't support bind mounting from the host, presumably as
  it defeats the portability that is a goal of that format: one would
  have to write a bunch of code to start a series of containers with
  bind mounts to the host.

* One needs to dispose of temporary directories when an Executor is
  completely done with. So one needs to bloat a new operator to dispose
  of it, as well as fields to track what to clean up.  And, that
  clean-up has failure modes, too.

* The CONTROL_DIR hot loading support needs to move and create files,
  and file UID/GID mapping through bind mounts in other containers is
  complex.  It gets worse when one considers how boot2docker does file
  sharing on Macintosh: then *three* possible interpretations or
  mangling of file UIDs come into play.

Finally, the useful part about CONTROL_DIR -- the ability to poll and
hot-load the contents -- is not employed at all inside a container,
because a new release triggers a start of a new container, and that's a
perfect opportunity to inject the immutable HSUP_CONTROL_GOB.  This
fastidiousness is of little consequence if the system degenerated well
otherwise, but it did not.  The HSUP_CONTROL_GOB style, sacrificing the
never-used hot-updates, eliminates a ton of complexity, and teaches an
object lesson: do not underestimate file management and containers.

commit_list.repo_description: Supervises processes that are configured in a Heroku-esque way.

commit_list.message:
Use "input" as the state machine abstraction

Previously, the model was that a "goal" would be prescribed for the
state machine in an effort to spare some more entities in the data
model, but in the end that wound up feeling strange and obscure to deal
with certain impulses to the system (e.g. restarting).

Instead, split the "input" and "state" domains (See DynoInput) and
remove the now unnecessary "NonState" entity to get hysteresis of old
inputs.

Also, epsilon moves are now handled with "goto again" rather than
triggering a tick via Goroutine.  The former was useful to put stress on
the concurrency model, but overwrought to the purpose.

commit_list.message: Update readme file names to match "-2" Heroku rev

Use PHP built with --enable-sockets

Again, this flag was not seen in old versions, so it's unclear how
this functionality, per secondary report, was regressed.

Build instructions updated accordingly.

Update binary vendoring steps in README

For Apache 2.2.25 and PHP 5.3.27.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

* Silence GNU Make steps via '-s' to quiet down builds (warnings are
  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default
  paths and can't be done in-dyno.  This makes the steps for dealing
  with 'APC' much simpler.

* Use default responses for prompts when building APC rather than
  prompting the builder.

* Sanitize cgi-bin of default Apache programs.

* Create binary-vendoring tarballs with the same name that they are
  intended to be uploaded as.

  Notably, name of the tarball and the directory contained within that
  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.

Use new Apache and PHP binaries

Remove gratuitous and dangerous global variable

It may have prevented GC churn, but the bugs it can cause under
concurrency are going to be weird and terrible.  This is more like a
style used in all the other functions anyway, with a slice pointing to
a stack value.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Remove debugging prints from test

This causes noise on the screen when running 'go test'.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Rename packBuffer.go to pack_buffer.go

This seems to be the canonical way file names are handled in Go, ref
Go net package.  In particular, case sensitivity can cause edge cases
on different platforms that underscores do not.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>
Make testing language more concrete and shorter

Implement parallelized, pipelined prefetching of WAL

This is intended to achieve a drastic performance increase in WAL
application in many situations.

This is done by using some temporary directories and daemonized
sub-processes, implement a prefetcher that can hopefully pipeline
downloading WAL to be applied while Postgres is performing other WAL
recovery.

Fix channel shim test for gevent 1.0.0

Gevent 1.0 specifies this as its version, not 1.0.0, breaking the
comparison spuriously if one has version 1.0 installed exactly.

Remove non-deterministic test case

This would sometimes fail on Travis-CI giving spurious failures, and
doesn't test a vitally distinct path.
Add Raanan Raz as a contributor

Use pip instead of default sdist

Before, OpenStack dependencies would cause obscure crashes when
setting up virtual environments because "python setup.py develop" is
not supported on account of its easy_install use.  The OpenStack
maintainers show negative interest in fixing that.

Fold the introduction below the title, use the standard subtitle

This makes the Table of Contents render a little nicer, and after the
couple of sentences of introductory test.

Edit PyPI metadata title to be more accurate

No longer is this an S3 only tool.  The title has been made the same
as the mailing list's title.

Fix __exit__ in contexts

The return value of __exit__ is used to determine if Python should
re-raise exceptions, False meaning 're-raise'.

The dangerous looking one is the one in StreamPadFileObj, where a
.close() that might somehow yield a non-False-ish return could cause
exceptions to be swallowed.

It doesn't seem likely that'd ever be the case, but the code as
written needlessly relies on that for correct behavior and obscures
the intent.

Backpatch this change to 0.5, too.

Fix buckets in S3-Classic/US-Standard that have dots

us-standard buckets that have dots ('.'), but are otherwise subdomain
compatible and could successfully run get_location(), which would
return '' (empty string), which is not seen in the region dictionary,
causing WAL-E to crash.

The fix is to re-write a successful get_location() of '' to
'us-standard'.

A regression test has been added.

This was not exercised by previous testing because all of them
combined other strangeness of bucket-name (like upper-case) that would
cause defaulting to us-standard.  Also, those that use an IAM set up
that does not permit get_location would not see this regression.

Reported by Christophe Pettus
Add missing contributors

Apply tar member cardinality limit to segments

To avoid excessive memory usage in database clusters that have many,
many very tiny files that can be jammed into one partition.

Fix set notation use in subprocess.py

It doesn't seem like this should be committed to Python.org in a file
that claims to be 2.2 compatible.  Probably worth a bug report.

Enfeeble failing subprocess doctests

These seem to have specific dates and require specific error messages
from basic POSIX utilities.  This patch is split out to explicitly
document the hacks applied to subprocess.

Copy in and use a recent version of subprocess module

The subprocess source advertises to working all the way back to Python
2.2, so it should be a strict superset of WAL-E supported Python
versions (2.6+).

Although bugs in subprocess have been worked around before in WAL-E,
the final straw leading to this nuclear option is is issue #16327[0],
which causes file descriptor leaks within subprocess in event of fork
failure, which after the fork()-OOM-retry patch become much more
severe.

In that latter case, a vicious cycle forms wherein failed fork()s leak
resources (leaked file handles), causing the parent process to grow,
which increases the memory spike required for fork-exec, making future
forks more likely to fail.  WAL-E can die in that case from the file
descriptor leak.

[0]: http://bugs.python.org/issue16327

Skip 'wal-e version' test if wal-e not in PATH

A better fix would be to exercise the code without wal-e being in
PATH, but skipping is better than noise.

Update HISTORY.rst

Subtract un-necessary word.
Pick up PHP with --enable-sockets after v10 of the build pack
Pick up PHP with --enable-sockets after v10 of the build pack

  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.

Both format string confusion.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Regenerate OID table and make it public

Also document how the table is generated.  This has been generated
from a build of PostgreSQL 9.2.3.

Previously, Oids above 10000 were included, but these are not
guaranteed to remain stable between releases and don't seem very
useful besides, so they are now omitted.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Editorialize comments

Right now there is no obvious way to push command tags through
database/sql, so just drop it on the floor.  libpq does little more
than report it and transition the state machine to 'READY', and as of
now Go pq has no state machine model to speak of.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Support timestamp without tz, redux

This time, some more effort has been paid to testing on an older Go
version, 1.0.2, and carefully preserving the old hacks to make time
parsing work with those older versions with a less useful time.Parse.
It has also been tested on Go 1.0.3.

This just lets the Go time package use its default behavior when one
is left without time offset information.  Hope it is a behavior people
want.

The main change here is pushing down the column type into the parsing
function, as Go's time parsing can't deal with data that only has the
fractional-hour timezone offset when such a fraction exists
(e.g. "-07" for "-07:00", but "-7:30" necessarily retaining its
precision).  This old hack could not be applied unconditionally (it is
wrong when the timestamp has no time zone offset suffix), so this
information lets a correct decision be made.

Clearly, this approach also can't handle the Postgres datestyle
parameter, but that's a fight to pick some other time.

As a target of opportunity, move the 'oid' type to 'types.go', since
for now all oids I know of handled by the program are type oids.  This
causes 'go fmt' to go a little nuts and rewrite the long but boring
file.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Revert "Support timestamp without tz"

Seems to work on some older or younger go devel, but not on a release
version, it seems.

This reverts commit 7f1933fdbdec31350abc6a616463eb85653fee31.

This reverts commit 7f1933fdbdec31350abc6a616463eb85653fee31.

Support timestamp without tz

This just lets Go's time package do what it is going to by default
when one is left without offset information.  Hope it's a behavior
people want.

The main change here is pushing down the column type into the parsing
function, as Go's time parsing can't deal with data that only has the
fractional-hour timezone offset when such a fraction exists
(e.g. "-07" for "-07:00", but "-7:30" necessarily retaining its
precision).  This old hack could not be applied unconditionally (it is
wrong when the timestamp has no time zone offset suffix), so this
information lets a correct decision be made.

Clearly, this approach also can't handle the Postgres datestyle
parameter, but that's a fight to pick some other time.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>
Update readme file names to match "-2" Heroku rev

Use PHP built with --enable-sockets

Again, this flag was not seen in old versions, so it's unclear how
this functionality, per secondary report, was regressed.

Build instructions updated accordingly.

Update binary vendoring steps in README

For Apache 2.2.25 and PHP 5.3.27.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

* Silence GNU Make steps via '-s' to quiet down builds (warnings are
  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default
  paths and can't be done in-dyno.  This makes the steps for dealing
  with 'APC' much simpler.

* Use default responses for prompts when building APC rather than
  prompting the builder.

* Sanitize cgi-bin of default Apache programs.

* Create binary-vendoring tarballs with the same name that they are
  intended to be uploaded as.

  Notably, name of the tarball and the directory contained within that
  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.
Use new Apache and PHP binaries

commit_list.message:
Add and use gob poller for self-invocations

This piggybacks on the CONTROL_DIR json-demarshalling structures to
serialize a gob passed by environment, allowing hsup to invoke itself
inside containers in both build and execution phases with rich
information and through a single mechanism, cleaning up all the
inspection of how hsup was configured when pushing data into the
sub-invocation.

Unlike the other pollers, the gob poller will only ever send exactly one
"Processes" value.

Detailed design information follows:

While this patch solves more problems than it creates, it exposes and
exacerbates some cracks in the software engineering:

Firstly, the guts of one poller (the "ControlDir") is shared between two
pollers, one of which has nothing to do with a directories.  To make
matters worse, its serialization/deserialization is in the guts of a
DynoDriver.

Superficially, this is an alarming destruction of abstraction barriers,
but not so much in light of what a "ControlDir" is at a detailed level:
to be a compact, no-frills, serializable data structure describing all
the same data any poller needs to respond.  It is the concrete variant
of the interface-driven approach used to return data from pollers
thusfar (e.g. the "Formation" interface).

In light of how useful serializing rich values to instruct descended
hsup processes is, perhaps all pollers ought to be adjusted to yield a
single, concrete implementation (that would be exactly like
"ControlDir") rather than support any kind of polymorphism via
interfaces as is currently the case.

This organizational and naming snarl is worthwhile removing if this
patch survives service to a larger goal: making the CONTROL_DIR
functionality work, and in particular supporting both http and
file-driven image building.  Before, this was busted and it appeared it
some futzing around with volumes and binds to fix it, but I found this
harder than anticipated when trying to achieve it.

On this unexpected difficulty: I chose this design after experimenting
with another.  That approach was using the CONTROL_DIR format to teach
the hsup self-invocation what to do.  Implied in this is file
generation, manipulation, and particularly sharing, and in this are the
seeds of that approach's undoing:

* There a lot more that can go wrong that requires error handling in
  code paths where one can do without such failure modes.

* Dockerfiles don't support bind mounting from the host, presumably as
  it defeats the portability that is a goal of that format: one would
  have to write a bunch of code to start a series of containers with
  bind mounts to the host.

* One needs to dispose of temporary directories when an Executor is
  completely done with. So one needs to bloat a new operator to dispose
  of it, as well as fields to track what to clean up.  And, that
  clean-up has failure modes, too.

* The CONTROL_DIR hot loading support needs to move and create files,
  and file UID/GID mapping through bind mounts in other containers is
  complex.  It gets worse when one considers how boot2docker does file
  sharing on Macintosh: then *three* possible interpretations or
  mangling of file UIDs come into play.

Finally, the useful part about CONTROL_DIR -- the ability to poll and
hot-load the contents -- is not employed at all inside a container,
because a new release triggers a start of a new container, and that's a
perfect opportunity to inject the immutable HSUP_CONTROL_GOB.  This
fastidiousness is of little consequence if the system degenerated well
otherwise, but it did not.  The HSUP_CONTROL_GOB style, sacrificing the
never-used hot-updates, eliminates a ton of complexity, and teaches an
object lesson: do not underestimate file management and containers.

Indirect API use for Formations

For the purpose of improving testing and use cases involving
non-Heroku-API injection of input into hsup.

Also, eliminate the boxing of Executors in Formations:

Once I started eliminating unused fields from Formation, it was looking
very anemic, and it didn't seem worthwhile to make a complex
relationship between Executors and some other kind of value merely
to (re)start the program under supervision.

What is lost from this reduction of bookkeeping express itemization of
values like "Quantity" and some things like "Type" are duplicated among
Executors.

commit_list.message:
Use "input" as the state machine abstraction

Previously, the model was that a "goal" would be prescribed for the
state machine in an effort to spare some more entities in the data
model, but in the end that wound up feeling strange and obscure to deal
with certain impulses to the system (e.g. restarting).

Instead, split the "input" and "state" domains (See DynoInput) and
remove the now unnecessary "NonState" entity to get hysteresis of old
inputs.

Also, epsilon moves are now handled with "goto again" rather than
triggering a tick via Goroutine.  The former was useful to put stress on
the concurrency model, but overwrought to the purpose.

commit_list.message: Increment copyright year of time.rs

Use passing by-value in gmtime, mktime

Per the recommendation of the now-removed FIXME.

Remove unnecessary 'use' forms

Fix a laundry list of warnings involving unused imports that glutted
up compilation output.  There are more, but there seems to be some
false positives (where 'remedy' appears to break the build), but this
particular set of fixes seems safe.

Use os._exit instead of sys.exit

The latter propagates a SystemExit exception in the transient child
forks.  It is unlikely a user wants exception unwinding to happen
several times when daemonizing, rather, just once when the process ends.

Finally, this prevents drop-in compatibility with the older
python-daemon package.  It exits processes this way, and the difference
does amount to rendering pep3143daemon unusable with py.test, which
emits very confused output when SystemExit is raised by sys.exit several
times.

Provide an example of the keyring format.

Rather than having to sight-read it from the instructions. Perhaps there is a way to make the overall documentation more terse to offset the addition of an example.

Fix a laundry list of warnings involving unused imports that glutted
up compilation output.  There are more, but there seems to be some
false positives (where 'remedy' appears to break the build), but this
particular set of fixes seems safe.

Per the recommendation of the now-removed FIXME.

Avoid quadratic string append for WABS

Fix this classic inefficiency of using immutable concatenations.

Suppress start-up log message in some common cases

In particular, `wal-fetch`, `wal-push`, `wal-prefetch`, and the case
where no subcommand is presented.
Fix bytes/string mismatch in reading psql output
Add v1.0.0 Release Notes

Update dependency version constraints in setup.py

`setup.py`'s version constraints are left over from the Python2
versions of WAL-E. These new version numbers are copied from
`tox.ini`'s `v1.0-oldest` environment.

Fix boto-importing issues seen on Travis

Though `boto` is compatible with Python 3.4 and Python 3.5, Travis has
a plugin installed that is only Python2 compatible.  As a kludge,
remove the plugin when running on Travis.

This is worrisome  in general because a regular  `WAL-E` install could
run into the same issue, but if the alternative is remain on Python 2,
then there is not much of a choice.
Modify distutils classifiers to indicate new Python versions

Fix v1.0-oldest tox environment

Tox would previously complain about doubly-specified dependencies.

Increment oldest version of supported gcloud

This should have been part of
9bba3fc499b9df8a1bd32d9dc3d32ae18a335f7f: older versions of `gcloud`
require the project name environment variable.
Add Andrew Marks as a contributor
Add google keywords, reflecting GCS support
Update the maintainer email address

Make storage backends optional

Unfortunately, upstream drivers have been found wanting: they are not
reliable to install.  Most of the trouble is with OpenStack, and GCS
has not been reliable either.

I have long resisted this as I thought it was silly to have the
simplest installation of WAL-E be useless, but the unreliability of
all the dependent drivers has forced my hand.  The last straw was
Google.

Implement Python 3.4 and 3.5 support

These changes fix all known issues that cannot be fixed with the
`2to3` tool.

Eliminate subprocess backport

As WAL-E now relies on a new Python, the bug-fixes copied in from
newer `subprocess.py`s is now unnecessary.  See
1bce8a6faa03947dcf5e898af22f27e276cb9bc8.

Perform 2to3 run on WAL-E

Though broken, this is broken into its own commit so that one can tell
apart automatically converted source from hand-fixed source.

This was useful in the past when doing multiple 2to3 passes at various
points in history.

Remove extraneous GCLOUD_PROJECT requirement

This is not used anywhere, and the `GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS`
json document has the project name included.

Increase pool size for wal-push to 32

I've measured significant performance increases on large instances,
AWS EC2 `r3.8xlarge` in my case, with a larger parallel push setting.

Update cipher suites in test_cipher_suites

In at least some regions, AWS has since moved on to the new and fancy
GCM mechanism, so add it to the cipher suite whitelist.

Fix environment variable clearing in log tests

This causes all sorts of mayhem in later tests that rely on integration
test environment variables, for example. This was introduced in
fedb9ecb762cb80edb7b71bce5db5c87ee6f1b5b, along with the feature it
tests.

Fix broken Google Storage integration tests

These could not have worked at any point: the way buckets were managed
was entirely wrong.  This became more obvious after fixing
c3e6d1862df389b7f5079d6b16212c2e3681f9cf, which allowed integration
tests to run properly.

Mangle bucket name in test_empty_latest_listing

This would always use the same bucket name in S3, which means that only
one person in the world (me) could run this test successfully.  Everyone
else would get a timeout.

The bucket name mangler was introduced to solve this problem, but it was
omitted here before.

Streamline testing instructions and add Google

Remove superfluous detail from the README.  There is some information in
there that is obsolete: testing Python 2.6 isn't supported for some time
now and so isn't as important as it once was.  And nobody has submitted
a `unittest`-style test for a long time.

Expend some of that gained simplicity to add Google integration test
instructions.

Re-introduce flake8 exemptions for vendored code

This caused excess noise in test runs.  This was introduced in
4f1722a116e90053035dd434695465110aa8b77a.

Turn off wal-fetch parallelism in test

py.test interactly poorly with the daemonization/forking of wal-fetch
and prefetching, causing the number of Python processes to explode. It
can easily slow a modern machine to a crawl.

Use a list comprehension rather than a map

It is allegedly a preferred mechanism.

Avoid comparison of integer to None

This is a crash in Python3.

Open /dev/null as a binary stream

There is no reason to interpret the bit-bucketed strings as text.  This
can cause crashes on python3.
Use a supported fork of pytest-capturelog

Pass test environment variables

New versions of tox do not pass the environment by default, and so
integration tests will not run as one expect given the instructions.
Thus, pass those environment variables.
Use modern exception catching syntax

Add AWS STS and instance-metadata clarification

Add earsdown to CONTRIBUTORS

Seeing as how this submitter has declined to give an email, the Github
URL seems like the next best thing.

Start v1.0 branch

Add Kenneth Shelton to CONTRIBUTORS

Per what's on his Github nowadays.

Add Kenny Johansson as a contributor
Add Feike Steenbergen to CONTRIBUTORS
Add Anatolii Mihailenco to CONTRIBUTORS

Revert "Disable query timeout for backup push."

This reverts commit 36e2050cf709251cd4e2002d461e16ef9a7009c3.

Drop support for Python 2.6

Because the Azure driver has since dropped support and this was making
test failures noisy.

As a bonus, test failures resulting from skew in the semantics of
exceptions in "pytest.raises") go away.

Suppress warnings in newer versions of pep8

It's not worth fixing these in a point release.  Maybe next version.
Fix PEP8/pyflakes failures in pep3143daemon

Switch PEP3143 Daemon Implementation

Previously, there was some complaint that python-daemon is an annoying
dependency to have.  What sealed its fate is that it depends on an
obsolete version of "lockfile", and that makes it an unacceptable pain
to vendor it and its dependencies when necessary.

Instead, vendor an implementation from Stephan Schultchen, as seen at
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pep3143daemon.  This doesn't require
lockfile and is smaller.  This project is distributed under MIT, and the
version copied is from a modified version that fixes an obscure
difference in how processes are exited:
https://github.com/fdr/pep3143daemon/commit/5c091da7f5a912bc35e349fa4d0249915c233813

Make parallel upload pass on missing segments

This code was designed under the supposition that the
"pg_xlog/archive_status" directory would always have corresponding
"pg_xlog" files.  There are a couple of documented cases where this is
not true, at least one involving pg_upgrade.

Instead of crashing the process in such a case preventing progress,
allow parallel uploads not explicitly requested by Postgres succeed.

Avoid some problematic paths in backup tars

In particular, "promote" files that can be left by "pg_ctl promote", and
"lost+found" directories left by fsck programs.

The former was reported by Thomas van Noort.
The latter was reprted by Alexey Sveshnikov.

Support double-closing of pipe reading/writers

This is consistent with a normal file in Python, e.g.:

    >>> f = open('/dev/null')
    >>> f.close()
    >>> f.close()
    >>>

Failures to "del self._bd" -- presumably from multiple .close() calls --
have caused a number of confusing stack traces in various situations.

The order of operations here have been carefully re-ordered so that the
invalidation used to assert closed-ness (self._fd = -1) can only occur
if the delegated "_fp.close()" succeeds.  And, in case of any raised
asynchronous exception, the "del attr" constructs have been made
optional, as so close() can be called after an exception and "closed"
reports properly.
Add Paul Paradise as a contributor
Allow new ECDHE cipher suite in test
Add Hunter Blanks as a contributor
Add Chris Armstrong as a contributor

Make WABS Range support Python 2.6

Format strings in Python 2.6 do not support the anonymous '{}' for
ordinal interpolation.
Make testing language more concrete and shorter

Implement parallelized, pipelined prefetching of WAL

This is intended to achieve a drastic performance increase in WAL
application in many situations.

This is done by using some temporary directories and daemonized
sub-processes, implement a prefetcher that can hopefully pipeline
downloading WAL to be applied while Postgres is performing other WAL
recovery.

Fix channel shim test for gevent 1.0.0

Gevent 1.0 specifies this as its version, not 1.0.0, breaking the
comparison spuriously if one has version 1.0 installed exactly.

Remove non-deterministic test case

This would sometimes fail on Travis-CI giving spurious failures, and
doesn't test a vitally distinct path.
Add Raanan Raz as a contributor

Use pip instead of default sdist

Before, OpenStack dependencies would cause obscure crashes when
setting up virtual environments because "python setup.py develop" is
not supported on account of its easy_install use.  The OpenStack
maintainers show negative interest in fixing that.

Fold the introduction below the title, use the standard subtitle

This makes the Table of Contents render a little nicer, and after the
couple of sentences of introductory test.

Edit PyPI metadata title to be more accurate

No longer is this an S3 only tool.  The title has been made the same
as the mailing list's title.

Fix __exit__ in contexts

The return value of __exit__ is used to determine if Python should
re-raise exceptions, False meaning 're-raise'.

The dangerous looking one is the one in StreamPadFileObj, where a
.close() that might somehow yield a non-False-ish return could cause
exceptions to be swallowed.

It doesn't seem likely that'd ever be the case, but the code as
written needlessly relies on that for correct behavior and obscures
the intent.

Backpatch this change to 0.5, too.

Fix buckets in S3-Classic/US-Standard that have dots

us-standard buckets that have dots ('.'), but are otherwise subdomain
compatible and could successfully run get_location(), which would
return '' (empty string), which is not seen in the region dictionary,
causing WAL-E to crash.

The fix is to re-write a successful get_location() of '' to
'us-standard'.

A regression test has been added.

This was not exercised by previous testing because all of them
combined other strangeness of bucket-name (like upper-case) that would
cause defaulting to us-standard.  Also, those that use an IAM set up
that does not permit get_location would not see this regression.

Reported by Christophe Pettus
Add missing contributors

Apply tar member cardinality limit to segments

To avoid excessive memory usage in database clusters that have many,
many very tiny files that can be jammed into one partition.

Fix set notation use in subprocess.py

It doesn't seem like this should be committed to Python.org in a file
that claims to be 2.2 compatible.  Probably worth a bug report.

Enfeeble failing subprocess doctests

These seem to have specific dates and require specific error messages
from basic POSIX utilities.  This patch is split out to explicitly
document the hacks applied to subprocess.

Copy in and use a recent version of subprocess module

The subprocess source advertises to working all the way back to Python
2.2, so it should be a strict superset of WAL-E supported Python
versions (2.6+).

Although bugs in subprocess have been worked around before in WAL-E,
the final straw leading to this nuclear option is is issue #16327[0],
which causes file descriptor leaks within subprocess in event of fork
failure, which after the fork()-OOM-retry patch become much more
severe.

In that latter case, a vicious cycle forms wherein failed fork()s leak
resources (leaked file handles), causing the parent process to grow,
which increases the memory spike required for fork-exec, making future
forks more likely to fail.  WAL-E can die in that case from the file
descriptor leak.

[0]: http://bugs.python.org/issue16327

Skip 'wal-e version' test if wal-e not in PATH

A better fix would be to exercise the code without wal-e being in
PATH, but skipping is better than noise.

Subtract un-necessary word.

Update binary vendoring steps in README

For Apache 2.2.25 and PHP 5.3.27.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

* Silence GNU Make steps via '-s' to quiet down builds (warnings are
  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default
  paths and can't be done in-dyno.  This makes the steps for dealing
  with 'APC' much simpler.

* Use default responses for prompts when building APC rather than
  prompting the builder.

* Sanitize cgi-bin of default Apache programs.

* Create binary-vendoring tarballs with the same name that they are
  intended to be uploaded as.

  Notably, name of the tarball and the directory contained within that
  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default

Support timestamp without tz, redux

This time, some more effort has been paid to testing on an older Go
version, 1.0.2, and carefully preserving the old hacks to make time
parsing work with those older versions with a less useful time.Parse.
It has also been tested on Go 1.0.3.

This just lets the Go time package use its default behavior when one
is left without time offset information.  Hope it is a behavior people
want.

The main change here is pushing down the column type into the parsing
function, as Go's time parsing can't deal with data that only has the
fractional-hour timezone offset when such a fraction exists
(e.g. "-07" for "-07:00", but "-7:30" necessarily retaining its
precision).  This old hack could not be applied unconditionally (it is
wrong when the timestamp has no time zone offset suffix), so this
information lets a correct decision be made.

Clearly, this approach also can't handle the Postgres datestyle
parameter, but that's a fight to pick some other time.

As a target of opportunity, move the 'oid' type to 'types.go', since
for now all oids I know of handled by the program are type oids.  This
causes 'go fmt' to go a little nuts and rewrite the long but boring
file.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

people want.

Previously, a change in the level of indirection of a field in a
struct is changed (inlined, single-pointer, double-pointer, etc) would

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Add a series of negative tests for incorrect input

This required a relatively large rearrangement to the testing
infrastructure to break out detecing problems from failing the testing
package directly.

In addition, the default fail mode has been switched to Fail() from
Fatal(), as so multiple astRegressions can be run in one test.  This
is easier to read, even if it sacrifices a potential parallelization
opportunity sometimes.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Correct Action parsing to absorb its own right-brace

Previously, input like "[route 'bar' @ 137 [delete]" would parse
properly because the extra-right-braces would not be absorbed by the
action-parsing, but instead by the toplevel parsing.

The result when parsing more credible input is that unconsumed input
intended for the last emitted AST can be left in the scanner.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Scan errors now cause scanning to stop

Previously, they'd emit some stderr and continue.  To abort from deep
within the scanner, a more complex mechanism than one might expect
using panic/recovery unwinding seems necessary.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Reform parser.go to emit more classical AST

These AST nodes, seen in syntax_types, all have roots in Token values,
which allows for error reporting (including the position of the error)
when the tree is semantically analyzed.

The tests have been updated to reflect these new structures.  Notably
they all now contain positioning information in the emitted structure.

Prior to this, some amount of semantic analysis was done while parsing
(such as converting tokens into integers, et al) in an attempt to end
up with structures more similar to what was predicted to be necessary
at run-time.  This has effectively been removed, and needs to be
re-introduced as a pass on top of the AST, per-normal compiler
architecture.

fmtPointer has been completely gutted to prevent accidentally calling

the stable package as of yet, because it is thought that any path that
matters is already treated.

Sort stability on maps has also been fixed by the addition of
retrieving the interface value of a reflect.Value before printing.
The string rendering of reflect.Value contains non-deterministic
information that would be considered in the sort.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Add vertical whitespace and indentation to output

existing functionality, though.

A modified "fmt" package from Go is used to do this, to overcome
problems with non-deterministic output order of maps.

Output of the astRegress function ends up in the 'results' directory,
and then compared to their equivalents in the 'expected' directory.

Inspired by pg_regress in PostgreSQL.

commit_list.message:
Do not retry close() on EINTR

This would represent file descriptor corruption in a multi-threaded
program (since the file descriptor number could be reused), but as
Postgres has no such execution such a loop seems harmless for now: the
second loop after EINTR would result in a prectable EBADF and then
subsequently exit.

commit_list.message:
Add custom formatting of LogRecord

Laborious but simple, this formats output in a key=value format.
Strings are carefully escaped with the %q format code, and nullable
strings, if set, have their contents (quoted) placed in square
brackets, or are represented with the literal NULL.  Numerical values
are unquoted. An example (word-wrapped):

2012/12/18 01:07:24 LogTime="2012-12-18 01:07:24.038 PST"
UserName=NULL DatabaseName=NULL Pid=11883 ClientAddr=NULL

commit_list.message: Initial commit
Update readme file names to match "-2" Heroku rev

Use PHP built with --enable-sockets

Again, this flag was not seen in old versions, so it's unclear how
this functionality, per secondary report, was regressed.

Build instructions updated accordingly.

Update binary vendoring steps in README

For Apache 2.2.25 and PHP 5.3.27.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

* Silence GNU Make steps via '-s' to quiet down builds (warnings are
  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default
  paths and can't be done in-dyno.  This makes the steps for dealing
  with 'APC' much simpler.

* Use default responses for prompts when building APC rather than
  prompting the builder.

* Sanitize cgi-bin of default Apache programs.

* Create binary-vendoring tarballs with the same name that they are
  intended to be uploaded as.

  Notably, name of the tarball and the directory contained within that
  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.
Use new Apache and PHP binaries

Remove unnecessary 'use' forms

Fix a laundry list of warnings involving unused imports that glutted
up compilation output.  There are more, but there seems to be some
false positives (where 'remedy' appears to break the build), but this
particular set of fixes seems safe.
Increment copyright year of time.rs

Use passing by-value in gmtime, mktime

Per the recommendation of the now-removed FIXME.
Add Chris Walsh as a contributor

commit_list.message:
Support timestamp without tz, redux

This time, some more effort has been paid to testing on an older Go
version, 1.0.2, and carefully preserving the old hacks to make time
parsing work with those older versions with a less useful time.Parse.
It has also been tested on Go 1.0.3.

This just lets the Go time package use its default behavior when one
is left without time offset information.  Hope it is a behavior people
want.

The main change here is pushing down the column type into the parsing
function, as Go's time parsing can't deal with data that only has the
fractional-hour timezone offset when such a fraction exists
(e.g. "-07" for "-07:00", but "-7:30" necessarily retaining its
precision).  This old hack could not be applied unconditionally (it is
wrong when the timestamp has no time zone offset suffix), so this
information lets a correct decision be made.

Clearly, this approach also can't handle the Postgres datestyle
parameter, but that's a fight to pick some other time.

As a target of opportunity, move the 'oid' type to 'types.go', since
for now all oids I know of handled by the program are type oids.  This
causes 'go fmt' to go a little nuts and rewrite the long but boring
file.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

commit_list.message:
TokenDB gives way and becomes ServeDB

The main idea behind this is to support multiple unix sockets to
listen on, as there is a marginal security advantage in that a
compromised LXC container and a poorly configured shared bind mount
(e.g. writable to programs within the container, but shared across
containers) could be used to intercept log traffic otherwise.

As an auxiliary feature, support invalidating old connections and
removal of unix-socket paths -- blindly -- specified in the database,
to prevent unix-socket rebinding errors when re-listening after a
database change.

A better way to handle that might be to accept a directory rather than
a socket path and provide a magically named sentinel file that can
help with both error detection and interlocking.  This is how
PostgreSQL's unix socket handling works.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

commit_list.message:
Identity to Token database support

Previously, the pg_logfebe identity field was used directly as the
logplex token.  Because the logplex token is deemed sensitive
information, it is desirable to not expose this to the postgresql
configuration, so introduce a layer of indirection in the form of the
token data base, where identities are mapped to real logplex tokens.

Change the 'make testdb' target to make 'tmp' a valid tokendb for
convenience.

not yet committed).  This was a pain when developing patches against
Postgres' HEAD while also working on pg_logplexcollector.

Change the 'PGSRCDIR' to setting to 'PGSRC', as now all git remotes
are supported as the source of the 'git archive' and 'PGSRCREMOTE'
seems too wordy, and 'PGSRCDIR' is a misnomer.

command is dangerous because if the user were to use a source tarball

Break apart main log processing loop

The main purpose of this is easing testing.  To this end, the
arguments to these procedures are procedure values that are pushed
down into the inner loops, with the intent that test versions of these
procedures can be injected.

exitFn is called when the function needs to exit with an error and
*must* panic.  The intention is it can jump directly to what should-be
the accompanying recover() in the provider of the exitFn.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

  prompting the builder.

  intended to be uploaded as.

  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.

Fix a laundry list of warnings involving unused imports that glutted

Sort by filename when generating INSERTs

Previously, the only thing keeping the output of .sql generation was

Instead of getting the tuples in any order, sort them by their
