commit_list.message:
Remove unnecessary 'use' forms

Fix a laundry list of warnings involving unused imports that glutted
up compilation output.  There are more, but there seems to be some
false positives (where 'remedy' appears to break the build), but this
particular set of fixes seems safe.

Ignore pg_replslot, pg_log, pg_wal when backing up

Ignoring `pg_log` is to avoid over-sized log files (over 2GiB) from
crashing backups.

Ignoring `pg_replslot`, a Postgres 9.6-ism, is to avoid stale
replication slots from causing retention of an unacceptable amount of
WAL.

`pg_wal` is going to be Postgres-10ism, a rename of `pg_xlog`, which
has always been ignored.
Begin v1.1 development

Fix new gevent given coros module deprecation

New versions of gevent no longer have a `coros` module, having renamed
that functionality to `lock`.  There was a deprecation warning for
this, and now it is finally gone for good.

This change has been around long enough that even the oldest supported
version of event in the Tox environment `v1.0-oldest` supports
importing `gevent.lock`, so change this without a concern for
backwards compatibility.
Add Joel Svensson as a contributor
Add Jamal Boukaffal to CONTRIBUTORS
Remove obsolete reference to argparse
Add Norbert Tretkowski as a contributor

Adhere to new flake8 restrictions

I think. These long-latent files have a few lines that no longer pass.
Add Joe Healy as a contributor
Add Derrick Petzold as a contributor
Add Ayush Goyal to CONTRIBUTORS
Add WABS Content-Type fix to RELEASES
Fix required Python version in README.rst
Add David Dever as a contributor

Fix erroneous RELEASES entry about wal-fetch

The change to default concurrency was only made to wal-push.

Avoid quadratic string append for WABS

Fix this classic inefficiency of using immutable concatenations.

Suppress start-up log message in some common cases

In particular, `wal-fetch`, `wal-push`, `wal-prefetch`, and the case
where no subcommand is presented.
Fix bytes/string mismatch in reading psql output
Add v1.0.0 Release Notes

Update dependency version constraints in setup.py

`setup.py`'s version constraints are left over from the Python2
versions of WAL-E. These new version numbers are copied from
`tox.ini`'s `v1.0-oldest` environment.

Fix boto-importing issues seen on Travis

Though `boto` is compatible with Python 3.4 and Python 3.5, Travis has
a plugin installed that is only Python2 compatible.  As a kludge,
remove the plugin when running on Travis.

This is worrisome  in general because a regular  `WAL-E` install could
run into the same issue, but if the alternative is remain on Python 2,
then there is not much of a choice.
Modify distutils classifiers to indicate new Python versions

Fix v1.0-oldest tox environment

Tox would previously complain about doubly-specified dependencies.

Increment oldest version of supported gcloud

This should have been part of
9bba3fc499b9df8a1bd32d9dc3d32ae18a335f7f: older versions of `gcloud`
require the project name environment variable.
Add Andrew Marks as a contributor
Add google keywords, reflecting GCS support
Update the maintainer email address

Make storage backends optional

Unfortunately, upstream drivers have been found wanting: they are not
reliable to install.  Most of the trouble is with OpenStack, and GCS
has not been reliable either.

I have long resisted this as I thought it was silly to have the
simplest installation of WAL-E be useless, but the unreliability of
all the dependent drivers has forced my hand.  The last straw was
Google.

Implement Python 3.4 and 3.5 support

These changes fix all known issues that cannot be fixed with the
`2to3` tool.

Eliminate subprocess backport

As WAL-E now relies on a new Python, the bug-fixes copied in from
newer `subprocess.py`s is now unnecessary.  See
1bce8a6faa03947dcf5e898af22f27e276cb9bc8.

Perform 2to3 run on WAL-E

Though broken, this is broken into its own commit so that one can tell
apart automatically converted source from hand-fixed source.

This was useful in the past when doing multiple 2to3 passes at various
points in history.

Remove extraneous GCLOUD_PROJECT requirement

This is not used anywhere, and the `GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS`
json document has the project name included.

Increase pool size for wal-push to 32

I've measured significant performance increases on large instances,
AWS EC2 `r3.8xlarge` in my case, with a larger parallel push setting.

Update cipher suites in test_cipher_suites

In at least some regions, AWS has since moved on to the new and fancy
GCM mechanism, so add it to the cipher suite whitelist.

Fix environment variable clearing in log tests

This causes all sorts of mayhem in later tests that rely on integration
test environment variables, for example. This was introduced in
fedb9ecb762cb80edb7b71bce5db5c87ee6f1b5b, along with the feature it
tests.

Fix broken Google Storage integration tests

These could not have worked at any point: the way buckets were managed
was entirely wrong.  This became more obvious after fixing
c3e6d1862df389b7f5079d6b16212c2e3681f9cf, which allowed integration
tests to run properly.

Mangle bucket name in test_empty_latest_listing

This would always use the same bucket name in S3, which means that only
one person in the world (me) could run this test successfully.  Everyone
else would get a timeout.

The bucket name mangler was introduced to solve this problem, but it was
omitted here before.

Streamline testing instructions and add Google

Remove superfluous detail from the README.  There is some information in
there that is obsolete: testing Python 2.6 isn't supported for some time
now and so isn't as important as it once was.  And nobody has submitted
a `unittest`-style test for a long time.

Expend some of that gained simplicity to add Google integration test
instructions.

Re-introduce flake8 exemptions for vendored code

This caused excess noise in test runs.  This was introduced in
4f1722a116e90053035dd434695465110aa8b77a.

Turn off wal-fetch parallelism in test

py.test interactly poorly with the daemonization/forking of wal-fetch
and prefetching, causing the number of Python processes to explode. It
can easily slow a modern machine to a crawl.

Use a list comprehension rather than a map

It is allegedly a preferred mechanism.

Avoid comparison of integer to None

This is a crash in Python3.

Open /dev/null as a binary stream

There is no reason to interpret the bit-bucketed strings as text.  This
can cause crashes on python3.
Use a supported fork of pytest-capturelog

Pass test environment variables

New versions of tox do not pass the environment by default, and so
integration tests will not run as one expect given the instructions.
Thus, pass those environment variables.
Use modern exception catching syntax
Add Matt Wright and Samuel Kohonen to Contributors
Add AWS STS and instance-metadata clarification

Add earsdown to CONTRIBUTORS

Seeing as how this submitter has declined to give an email, the Github
URL seems like the next best thing.
Modernize to use flake8 instead of pep8 and pyflakes
Start v1.0 branch
Alphabetize contributors
Add Masaki Muranaka as a contributor
Add Kenneth Shelton to CONTRIBUTORS

Update EvilPlankton's human name in CONTRIBUTORS

Per what's on his Github nowadays.
Add Léo Cavaillé as a contributor
Add Kenny Johansson as a contributor
Add Feike Steenbergen to CONTRIBUTORS
Add Anatolii Mihailenco to CONTRIBUTORS

Revert "Disable query timeout for backup push."

This reverts commit 36e2050cf709251cd4e2002d461e16ef9a7009c3.

Drop support for Python 2.6

Because the Azure driver has since dropped support and this was making
test failures noisy.

As a bonus, test failures resulting from skew in the semantics of
exceptions in "pytest.raises") go away.

Suppress warnings in newer versions of pep8

It's not worth fixing these in a point release.  Maybe next version.
Fix PEP8/pyflakes failures in pep3143daemon

Switch PEP3143 Daemon Implementation

Previously, there was some complaint that python-daemon is an annoying
dependency to have.  What sealed its fate is that it depends on an
obsolete version of "lockfile", and that makes it an unacceptable pain
to vendor it and its dependencies when necessary.

Instead, vendor an implementation from Stephan Schultchen, as seen at
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pep3143daemon.  This doesn't require
lockfile and is smaller.  This project is distributed under MIT, and the
version copied is from a modified version that fixes an obscure
difference in how processes are exited:
https://github.com/fdr/pep3143daemon/commit/5c091da7f5a912bc35e349fa4d0249915c233813

Make parallel upload pass on missing segments

This code was designed under the supposition that the
"pg_xlog/archive_status" directory would always have corresponding
"pg_xlog" files.  There are a couple of documented cases where this is
not true, at least one involving pg_upgrade.

Instead of crashing the process in such a case preventing progress,
allow parallel uploads not explicitly requested by Postgres succeed.

Avoid some problematic paths in backup tars

In particular, "promote" files that can be left by "pg_ctl promote", and
"lost+found" directories left by fsck programs.

The former was reported by Thomas van Noort.
The latter was reprted by Alexey Sveshnikov.

Support double-closing of pipe reading/writers

This is consistent with a normal file in Python, e.g.:

    >>> f = open('/dev/null')
    >>> f.close()
    >>> f.close()
    >>>

Failures to "del self._bd" -- presumably from multiple .close() calls --
have caused a number of confusing stack traces in various situations.

The order of operations here have been carefully re-ordered so that the
invalidation used to assert closed-ness (self._fd = -1) can only occur
if the delegated "_fp.close()" succeeds.  And, in case of any raised
asynchronous exception, the "del attr" constructs have been made
optional, as so close() can be called after an exception and "closed"
reports properly.
Add Paul Paradise as a contributor
Allow new ECDHE cipher suite in test
Add Hunter Blanks as a contributor
Add Chris Armstrong as a contributor

Make WABS Range support Python 2.6

Format strings in Python 2.6 do not support the anonymous '{}' for
ordinal interpolation.
Make testing language more concrete and shorter

Implement parallelized, pipelined prefetching of WAL

This is intended to achieve a drastic performance increase in WAL
application in many situations.

This is done by using some temporary directories and daemonized
sub-processes, implement a prefetcher that can hopefully pipeline
downloading WAL to be applied while Postgres is performing other WAL
recovery.

Fix channel shim test for gevent 1.0.0

Gevent 1.0 specifies this as its version, not 1.0.0, breaking the
comparison spuriously if one has version 1.0 installed exactly.

Remove non-deterministic test case

This would sometimes fail on Travis-CI giving spurious failures, and
doesn't test a vitally distinct path.
Add Raanan Raz as a contributor

Use pip instead of default sdist

Before, OpenStack dependencies would cause obscure crashes when
setting up virtual environments because "python setup.py develop" is
not supported on account of its easy_install use.  The OpenStack
maintainers show negative interest in fixing that.

Fold the introduction below the title, use the standard subtitle

This makes the Table of Contents render a little nicer, and after the
couple of sentences of introductory test.

Edit PyPI metadata title to be more accurate

No longer is this an S3 only tool.  The title has been made the same
as the mailing list's title.

Fix __exit__ in contexts

The return value of __exit__ is used to determine if Python should
re-raise exceptions, False meaning 're-raise'.

The dangerous looking one is the one in StreamPadFileObj, where a
.close() that might somehow yield a non-False-ish return could cause
exceptions to be swallowed.

It doesn't seem likely that'd ever be the case, but the code as
written needlessly relies on that for correct behavior and obscures
the intent.

Backpatch this change to 0.5, too.

Fix buckets in S3-Classic/US-Standard that have dots

us-standard buckets that have dots ('.'), but are otherwise subdomain
compatible and could successfully run get_location(), which would
return '' (empty string), which is not seen in the region dictionary,
causing WAL-E to crash.

The fix is to re-write a successful get_location() of '' to
'us-standard'.

A regression test has been added.

This was not exercised by previous testing because all of them
combined other strangeness of bucket-name (like upper-case) that would
cause defaulting to us-standard.  Also, those that use an IAM set up
that does not permit get_location would not see this regression.

Reported by Christophe Pettus
Add missing contributors

Apply tar member cardinality limit to segments

To avoid excessive memory usage in database clusters that have many,
many very tiny files that can be jammed into one partition.

Fix set notation use in subprocess.py

It doesn't seem like this should be committed to Python.org in a file
that claims to be 2.2 compatible.  Probably worth a bug report.

Enfeeble failing subprocess doctests

These seem to have specific dates and require specific error messages
from basic POSIX utilities.  This patch is split out to explicitly
document the hacks applied to subprocess.

Copy in and use a recent version of subprocess module

The subprocess source advertises to working all the way back to Python
2.2, so it should be a strict superset of WAL-E supported Python
versions (2.6+).

Although bugs in subprocess have been worked around before in WAL-E,
the final straw leading to this nuclear option is is issue #16327[0],
which causes file descriptor leaks within subprocess in event of fork
failure, which after the fork()-OOM-retry patch become much more
severe.

In that latter case, a vicious cycle forms wherein failed fork()s leak
resources (leaked file handles), causing the parent process to grow,
which increases the memory spike required for fork-exec, making future
forks more likely to fail.  WAL-E can die in that case from the file
descriptor leak.

[0]: http://bugs.python.org/issue16327

Skip 'wal-e version' test if wal-e not in PATH

A better fix would be to exercise the code without wal-e being in
PATH, but skipping is better than noise.

Update HISTORY.rst

Subtract un-necessary word.

Small readme fixups

This is an amendment vs the email version, but it seems worth
making...

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

README, in the form of email

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Initial commit

Signed-off-by: Daniel Farina <daniel@fdr.io>

Round up target fragment size to avoid tiny tail-end request

The integer floor division would result in a remainder of a few bytes
being done in its own request.  Chop this out by rounding up instead.

commit_list.message:
Program more defensively in eager_reader buffering

In particular, attempt to fail faster in event of lastError being set:
a mysterious hang condition was made a non-terminating one even though
it should have rapidly caused an "Unexpected EOF" error.

In the same vein, inject an EOF when the buffer fills rather than
relying on absolutely correct behavior from the underlying stream to
do so.

Also, upon re-reading this code at some length, I was left confused as
to how 'bufMu' is an alias into the 'more' condition variable's lock.
Rewrite this to be more verbose but re-enforce this relationship.

Remove vestigial chunkSize/targetFragSize tuning

Over time this will probably become more adaptive and less rule-based
anyway, and now some more complex logic is going on internal to HtCat,
so, remove it from the nascent API.
commit_list.repo_description: Parallel and Pipelined HTTP GET Utility

commit_list.message:
Furnish new ball-park benchmark numbers

I now think I understand why the 10MB (actually 13MB, amended to be
more accurate) file test was *so* slow, although it did not occur to
me at the time: S3-Classic/US-Standard may opt to home keys across the
continent from one's instance, and this does not seem to converge over
time (e.g. through mirroring).  So, this can be re-cast as a "slow
link" test.  It seems this can happen if one uploads to S3 from a
place geographically closer to Seattle, unless one uses the
s3-external-1 endpoint.  I uploaded the test file from such a
location.

So, I uploaded the file again from AWS us-east and re-took the
measurements, now affixed.

I tried another small key made from within EC2 us-east.  This has
become a new benchmark for "the very fast and very small" case, where
special code is triggered to avoid multi-request parallelism.
commit_list.repo_description: Parallel and Pipelined HTTP GET Utility

commit_list.message:
Deprecate use of HTTP HEAD: instead use GET piggy-backing

The general approach now is to run an non-Range GET first (instead of
a separate step using HEAD) to both determine the Content-Length and
also to start downloading bytes in one shot, rather than waiting for a
response to HEAD before beginning any bulk data transfer.

This both eliminates some startup time that can compound when dealing
with smaller GETs and can avoid failure when working against a server
that does not support HTTP HEAD in a situation where htcat would
otherwise work fine.

Remove the benchmark section showing slower times on very small files,
because that caveat has now been removed, as the gap has been reduced
to about one tenth of what it was previously.  My measurements of the
same suggest about a 10ms difference between 'curl' and 'htcat', a
small enough difference that adding a whole table to the README is
probably not very illuminating versus its cognitive load.

An oversight.

The following is an overview of some of the changes:

* Rewrite recipes into bash-script form

* Make re-entrant (via clearing /app) for easier iteration

* Use variable substitutions for version, directory, and archive names
  instead of repeating chunks of each all over the place.

* Make downloading optional, again to assist iteration.

* Silence GNU Make steps via '-s' to quiet down builds (warnings are
  still shown).

* Rely on the bash-ism pushd and popd to be more robust to slight
  changes in relative paths that may occur in the future.

* Rely on the PHP-distributed version of PEAR/PECL rather than the
  apt-get install version, which has a more dubious set of default
  paths and can't be done in-dyno.  This makes the steps for dealing
  with 'APC' much simpler.

* Use default responses for prompts when building APC rather than
  prompting the builder.

* Sanitize cgi-bin of default Apache programs.

* Create binary-vendoring tarballs with the same name that they are
  intended to be uploaded as.

  Notably, name of the tarball and the directory contained within that
  tarball will not match because the contained directory is devoid of
  version numbering, unlike the name of the tarball.
Use new Apache and PHP binaries
Add Dr. Nic Williams as a Contributor

Modernize .travis.yml

Driven by the fact that there is no Python 3.6 interpreter installed
by default.

Fix file descriptor leak from pipeline abort

Caught by `ResourceWarning`s in newer Pythons, the abort code fails to
clean up stdout file descriptors: go ahead and do so.

Squelch new warnings

Some `ResourceWarning`s have appeared, a number of them from tests
being lackadaisical about cleaning up resources.  So, clean them up.

Un-bitrot WABS/Azure Storage

After azure-storage v0.30, yet another rename of some functionality
has occurred.  So, separate the compatibility shim to avoid import
cyclicity and make the result of the shim available directly from
`wal_e.blobstore.wabs`.

This has the advantage of de-duplicating some code.
Add Greg Burek as a contributor
Add Alexander Kukushkin as a contributor

Avoid TravisCI boto plugins again

As of late, the `rm` command fails.  Accomplish something similar via
the advice in https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/5246.
Add secwall as a contributor
Update readme file names to match "-2" Heroku rev

Use PHP built with --enable-sockets

Again, this flag was not seen in old versions, so it's unclear how
this functionality, per secondary report, was regressed.

Build instructions updated accordingly.

Update binary vendoring steps in README

For Apache 2.2.25 and PHP 5.3.27.

As of now, the vendoring can now be done in a blank dyno rather
easily.  This process is now explained explicitly in the README.

Remove unnecessary 'use' forms

Fix a laundry list of warnings involving unused imports that glutted
up compilation output.  There are more, but there seems to be some
false positives (where 'remedy' appears to break the build), but this
particular set of fixes seems safe.
